name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: [NOISE] This

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: lecture is about the sentiment classification.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: If we assume that

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _most of the elements in the opinion representation are all ready known

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _then our only task may be just a sentiment classification

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _So suppose we know who's the opinion holder and what's the opinion target

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _and also know the content and the context of the opinion

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: decide the opinion sentiment of the review.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: So this is a case of just using sentiment classification for understanding opinion.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: Sentiment classification can be defined more specifically as follows.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _The input is opinionated text object
column6: the output is typically a sentiment label

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _or a sentiment tag
column6: and that can be designed in two ways. _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _One is polarity analysis
column6: where we have categories such as positive

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: or neutral.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: The other is emotion analysis that can go beyond

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: a polarity to characterize the feeling of the opinion holder.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _In the case of polarity analysis

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: also have numerical ratings as you often see in some reviews on the web.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _Five might denote the most positive
column6: and one maybe the most negative

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _In general
column6: you have just disk holder categories to characterize the sentiment. _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _In emotion analysis
column7: there are also different ways for _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: design the categories.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _The six most frequently used categories are happy

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _sad

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _So as you can see
column6: the task is essentially a classification task

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _task
column7: so it's a special case of text categorization. _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: This also means any textual categorization method can be used to do sentiment

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: classification.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _Now of course if you just do that
column6: the accuracy may not be good _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: because sentiment classification does requires some improvement over

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _regular text categorization technique

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _In particular
column6: it needs two kind of improvements. _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: One is to use more sophisticated features that may be more appropriate for

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: sentiment tagging as I will discuss in a moment.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _The other is to consider the order of these categories

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _especially in polarity analysis
column6: it's very clear there's an order here

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: and so these categories are not all that independent.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _There's order among them
column6: and so it's useful to consider the order. _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _For example
column6: we could use ordinal regression to do that

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: and that's something that we'll talk more about later.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _So now
column6: let's talk about some features that are often very useful for _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _text categorization and text mining in general

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: some of them are especially also needed for sentiment analysis.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _So let's start from the simplest one

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _You can just have a sequence of characters as a unit

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _and they can be mixed with different n's

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _All right
column6: and this is a very general way and _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: very robust way to represent the text data.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _And you could do that for any language

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _And this is also robust to spelling errors or recognition errors

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: So if you misspell a word by one character and this representation actually would

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: allow you to match this word when it occurs in the text correctly.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _Right
column6: so misspell the word and the correct form can be matched because _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: they contain some common n-grams of characters.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: But of course such a recommendation would not be as discriminating as words.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _So next
column7: a sequence of words and again

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: we can mix them with different n's.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: Unigram's are actually often very effective for a lot of text processing

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _tasks
column6: and it's mostly because words are word designed features by humans for _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _communication
column6: and so they are often good enough for many tasks. _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _But it's not good
column6: or not sufficient for sentiment analysis clearly. _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _For example
column6: we might see a sentence like

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _it's not good or it's not as good as something else

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: So in such a case if you just take a good and

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _that would suggest positive that's not good
column6: all right so it's not accurate. _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _But if you take a bigram

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _So longer n-grams are generally more discriminative

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _If you match it

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _it's accurate it's unlikely

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: But it may cause overfitting because with such very unique features that machine

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: oriented program can easily pick up such features from the training set and

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: to rely on such unique features to distinguish the categories.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _And obviously
column7: one would generalize word to future there when _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: such discriminative features will not necessarily occur.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: So that's a problem of overfitting that's not desirable.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _We can also consider part of speech tag
column6: n-grams if we can do part of _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _speech tagging an
column7: adjective noun could form a pair. _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: We can also mix n-grams of words and n-grams of part of speech tags.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _For example
column6: the word great might be followed by a noun

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _a feature
column7: that could be useful for sentiment analysis. _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: So next we can also have word classes.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _So these classes can be syntactic like a part of speech tags

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _and they might represent concepts in the thesaurus or ontology

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _Or they can be recognized the name entities

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: these categories can be used to enrich the presentation as additional features.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _We can also learn word clusters and parodically

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: we've talked about the mining associations of words.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: And so we can have cluster of paradigmatically related words or

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _syntaxmatically related words

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: these clusters can be features to supplement the word base representation.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _Furthermore
column6: we can also have frequent pattern syntax

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _these could be frequent word set

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: form the pattern do not necessarily occur together or next to each other.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: But we'll also have locations where

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _the words my occur more closely together

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: patterns provide a more discriminative features than words obviously.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: And they may also generalize better than just regular n-grams because they

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: are frequent.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: So you expected them to occur also in tested data.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _So they have a lot of advantages
column6: but they might still face the problem _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: of overfeeding as the features become more complex.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _This is a problem in general
column6: and the same is true for parse tree-based features

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _when you can use a parse tree to derive features such as frequent subtrees

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _paths
column6: and those are even more discriminating

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: they're also are more likely to cause over fitting.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _And in general
column6: pattern discovery algorithm's are very useful for _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: feature construction because they allow us to search in a large space of possible

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: features that are more complex than words that are sometimes useful.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _So in general
column6: natural language processing is very important that _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _they derive complex features
column6: and they can enrich text representation. _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _So for example

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: this is a simple sentence that I showed you a long time ago in another lecture.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _So from these words we can only derive simple word n-grams

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: representations or character n-grams.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _But with NLP

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _with a lot of other information such as part of speech tags

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _entities

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _Now with such enriching information of course
column6: then we can generate a lot _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _of other features
column6: more complex features like a mixed grams of a word and _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _the part of speech tags
column6: or even a part of a parse tree. _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _So in general
column6: feature design actually affects categorization accuracy _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _significantly
column6: and it's a very important part of any machine learning application. _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _In general
column6: I think it would be most effective if you can combine _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _machine learning
column7: and domain knowledge in design features. _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _So first you want to use the main knowledge

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _your understanding of the problem

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: you can also define a basic feature space with a lot of possible features for

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _the machine learning program to work on
column6: and machine can be applied to select _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: the most effective features or construct the new features.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _That's feature learning

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: these features can then be further analyzed by humans through error analysis.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _And you can look at the categorization errors

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _then further analyze what features can help you recover from those errors

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: or what features cause overfitting and cause those errors.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: And so this can lead into feature validation that will

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _revised the feature set

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: And we might consider using a different features space.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _So NLP enriches text recognition as I just said

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _because it enriches the feature space

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _it allows much larger such a space of features and there are also many

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: many more features that can be very useful for a lot of tasks.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: But be careful not to use a lot of category features because

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _it can cause overfitting

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: have to training careful not to let overflow happen.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _So a main challenge in design features

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: a common challenge is to optimize a trade off between exhaustivity and

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _the specificity
column6: and this trade off turns out to be very difficult. _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: Now exhaustivity means we want the features to actually have

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: high coverage of a lot of documents.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _And so in that sense
column6: you want the features to be frequent. _

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _Specifity requires the feature to be discriminative

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: naturally infrequent the features tend to be more discriminative.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: So this really cause a trade off between

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: frequent versus infrequent features.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: And that's why a featured design is usually odd.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: And that's probably the most important part in machine learning any

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: _problem in particularly in our case

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: more specifically the senitment classification.

name: 5 - 2 - 4.2 Opinion Mining and Sentiment Analysis- Sentiment Classification (00-11-47).srt
text: [MUSIC]
